segment.source: In this walkthrough, you will create and run your first experiment with A/B testing.
segment.target: In this walkthrough, you will create and run your first experiment with A/B testing.

segment.source: Create and run your first experiment with A/B testing
segment.target: Create and run your first experiment with A/B testing

segment.source: Create and run your first experiment with A/B testing
segment.target: Create and run your first experiment with A/B testing

segment.source: In this walkthrough, you will:
segment.target: In this walkthrough, you will:

segment.source: Create an experiment on the Windows Dev Center dashboard that tests whether changing the background color of an app button successfully increases the number of button clicks.
segment.target: Create an experiment on the Windows Dev Center dashboard that tests whether changing the background color of an app button successfully increases the number of button clicks.

segment.source: Create an app that retrieves variation settings from Dev Center, uses this data to change the background color of a button, and logs view and conversion event data to Dev Center.
segment.target: Create an app that retrieves variation settings from Dev Center, uses this data to change the background color of a button, and logs view and conversion event data to Dev Center.

segment.source: Run the app to gather experiment data.
segment.target: Run the app to gather experiment data.

segment.source: Review the experiment results on the Dev Center dashboard, choose a variation to enable for all users of the app, and complete the experiment.
segment.target: Review the experiment results on the Dev Center dashboard, choose a variation to enable for all users of the app, and complete the experiment.

segment.source: For an overview of A/B testing with Dev Center, see Run app experiments with A/B testing.
segment.target: For an overview of A/B testing with Dev Center, see Run app experiments with A/B testing.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: To follow this walkthrough, you must have a Windows Dev Center account and you must configure your development computer as described in Run app experiments with A/B testing.
segment.target: To follow this walkthrough, you must have a Windows Dev Center account and you must configure your development computer as described in Run app experiments with A/B testing.

segment.source: Create the experiment in Windows Dev Center
segment.target: Create the experiment in Windows Dev Center

segment.source: Sign in to the Dev Center dashboard.
segment.target: Sign in to the Dev Center dashboard.

segment.source: If you already have an app in Dev Center that you want to use to create an experiment, under Your apps, select the app.
segment.target: If you already have an app in Dev Center that you want to use to create an experiment, under Your apps, select the app.

segment.source: If you do not yet have an app in your dashboard, create a new app by reserving a name and then select that app in your dashboard.
segment.target: If you do not yet have an app in your dashboard, create a new app by reserving a name and then select that app in your dashboard.

segment.source: In the navigation pane, click Services and then click Experimentation.
segment.target: In the navigation pane, click Services and then click Experimentation.

segment.source: In the API keys section, select New API key to generate a new API key, and enter the name My First Experiment for the API key.
segment.target: In the API keys section, select New API key to generate a new API key, and enter the name My First Experiment for the API key.

segment.source: You will use this API key in the next section of this walkthrough.
segment.target: You will use this API key in the next section of this walkthrough.

segment.source: In the Experiments section, click New experiment.
segment.target: In the Experiments section, click New experiment.

segment.source: In the Experiment name field, type the name Optimize Button Clicks.
segment.target: In the Experiment name field, type the name Optimize Button Clicks.

segment.source: In the View event name field, type the name userViewedButton.
segment.target: In the View event name field, type the name userViewedButton.

segment.source: Later in this walkthrough, you will add code that logs this view event when the main page for your app is initialized and the button is visible to the user.
segment.target: Later in this walkthrough, you will add code that logs this view event when the main page for your app is initialized and the button is visible to the user.

segment.source: In the Goals and conversion events section, enter the following values:
segment.target: In the Goals and conversion events section, enter the following values:

segment.source: In the Goal name field, type Increase Button Clicks.
segment.target: In the Goal name field, type Increase Button Clicks.

segment.source: In the Conversion event name field, type the name userClickedButton.
segment.target: In the Conversion event name field, type the name userClickedButton.

segment.source: Later in this walkthrough, you will add code that logs this conversion event in the click event handler for the button.
segment.target: Later in this walkthrough, you will add code that logs this conversion event in the click event handler for the button.

segment.source: In the Objective field, choose Maximize.
segment.target: In the Objective field, choose Maximize.

segment.source: In the Variations and settings section, click Add setting three times.
segment.target: In the Variations and settings section, click Add setting three times.

segment.source: You should now have four rows of empty settings.
segment.target: You should now have four rows of empty settings.

segment.source: In the first row, type buttonText for the setting name, type Grey Button in the Variation A column, and type Blue Button in the Variation B column.
segment.target: In the first row, type buttonText for the setting name, type Grey Button in the Variation A column, and type Blue Button in the Variation B column.

segment.source: In the second row, type r for the setting name, type 128 in the Variation A column, and type 1 in the Variation B column.
segment.target: In the second row, type r for the setting name, type 128 in the Variation A column, and type 1 in the Variation B column.

segment.source: In the third row, type g for the setting name, type 128 in the Variation A column, and type 1 in the Variation B column.
segment.target: In the third row, type g for the setting name, type 128 in the Variation A column, and type 1 in the Variation B column.

segment.source: In the fourth row, type b for the setting name, type 128 in the Variation A column, and type 255 in the Variation B column.
segment.target: In the fourth row, type b for the setting name, type 128 in the Variation A column, and type 255 in the Variation B column.

segment.source: Confirm that the Distribute equally check box is selected so that the variations will be distributed equally to your app.
segment.target: Confirm that the Distribute equally check box is selected so that the variations will be distributed equally to your app.

segment.source: Click Save and then click Activate.
segment.target: Click Save and then click Activate.

segment.source: Important After you activate an experiment, you can no longer modify the experiment parameters unless it is a test experiment (you clicked the Test experiment check box when you created the experiment).
segment.target: Important After you activate an experiment, you can no longer modify the experiment parameters unless it is a test experiment (you clicked the Test experiment check box when you created the experiment).

segment.source: Typically, we recommend that you code the experiment in your app before activating your experiment.
segment.target: Typically, we recommend that you code the experiment in your app before activating your experiment.

segment.source: For simplicity, in this walkthrough you can activate the experiment now.
segment.target: For simplicity, in this walkthrough you can activate the experiment now.

segment.source: Code the experiment in your app
segment.target: Code the experiment in your app

segment.source: In Visual Studio 2015, create a new Universal Windows Platform project using Visual C#.
segment.target: In Visual Studio 2015, create a new Universal Windows Platform project using Visual C#.

segment.source: Name the project SampleExperiment.
segment.target: Name the project SampleExperiment.

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, expand your project node, right-click References, and click Add Reference.
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, expand your project node, right-click References, and click Add Reference.

segment.source: In Reference Manager, expand Universal Windows and click Extensions.
segment.target: In Reference Manager, expand Universal Windows and click Extensions.

segment.source: In the list of SDKs, select the check box next to Microsoft Store Engagement SDK and click OK.
segment.target: In the list of SDKs, select the check box next to Microsoft Store Engagement SDK and click OK.

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, double-click MainPage.xaml to open the designer for the main page in the app.
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, double-click MainPage.xaml to open the designer for the main page in the app.

segment.source: Drag a Button from Toolbox to the page.
segment.target: Drag a Button from Toolbox to the page.

segment.source: Double-click the button on the designer to open the code file and add an event handler for the Click event.
segment.target: Double-click the button on the designer to open the code file and add an event handler for the Click event.

segment.source: Replace the entire contents of the code file with the following code.
segment.target: Replace the entire contents of the code file with the following code.

segment.source: In the following line of code, assign the apiKey variable to the API key you obtained from the Dev Center dashboard in the previous section.
segment.target: In the following line of code, assign the apiKey variable to the API key you obtained from the Dev Center dashboard in the previous section.

segment.source: The API key shown below is for example purposes only.
segment.target: The API key shown below is for example purposes only.

segment.source: Save the code file and build the project.
segment.target: Save the code file and build the project.

segment.source: Run the app to gather experiment data
segment.target: Run the app to gather experiment data

segment.source: Run the SampleExperiment app you created in the previous section.
segment.target: Run the SampleExperiment app you created in the previous section.

segment.source: Confirm that you see either a grey or blue button.
segment.target: Confirm that you see either a grey or blue button.

segment.source: Click the button and then close the app.
segment.target: Click the button and then close the app.

segment.source: Repeat the above steps several times on the same computer to confirm that your app shows the same button color.
segment.target: Repeat the above steps several times on the same computer to confirm that your app shows the same button color.

segment.source: Review the results and complete the experiment
segment.target: Review the results and complete the experiment

segment.source: Wait at least several hours after completing the previous section, and then follow these steps to review the results of your experiment and complete the experiment.
segment.target: Wait at least several hours after completing the previous section, and then follow these steps to review the results of your experiment and complete the experiment.

segment.source: Note As soon as you activate an experiment, Dev Center immediately starts collecting data from any apps that are instrumented to log data for your experiment.
segment.target: Note As soon as you activate an experiment, Dev Center immediately starts collecting data from any apps that are instrumented to log data for your experiment.

segment.source: However, it can take several hours for experiment data to appear in the dashboard.
segment.target: However, it can take several hours for experiment data to appear in the dashboard.

segment.source: In Dev Center, return to the Experimentation page for your app.
segment.target: In Dev Center, return to the Experimentation page for your app.

segment.source: In the Experiments section, click the Active filter and then click Optimize Button Clicks to go to the page for this experiment.
segment.target: In the Experiments section, click the Active filter and then click Optimize Button Clicks to go to the page for this experiment.

segment.source: Confirm that the results shown in the Results summary and Results details sections matches what you expect to see.
segment.target: Confirm that the results shown in the Results summary and Results details sections matches what you expect to see.

segment.source: For more details about these sections, see Manage your experiment in the Dev Center dashboard.
segment.target: For more details about these sections, see Manage your experiment in the Dev Center dashboard.

segment.source: Note Dev Center reports only the first conversion event for each user in a 24-hour time period.
segment.target: Note Dev Center reports only the first conversion event for each user in a 24-hour time period.

segment.source: If a user triggers multiple conversion events in your app within a 24-hour period, only the first conversion event is reported.
segment.target: If a user triggers multiple conversion events in your app within a 24-hour period, only the first conversion event is reported.

segment.source: This is intended to help prevent a single user with many conversion events from skewing the experiment results for a sample group of users.
segment.target: This is intended to help prevent a single user with many conversion events from skewing the experiment results for a sample group of users.

segment.source: Now you are ready to end the experiment.
segment.target: Now you are ready to end the experiment.

segment.source: In the Results summary section, in the Variation B column, click Switch.
segment.target: In the Results summary section, in the Variation B column, click Switch.

segment.source: This switches all users of your app to the blue button.
segment.target: This switches all users of your app to the blue button.

segment.source: Click OK to confirm that you want to end the experiment.
segment.target: Click OK to confirm that you want to end the experiment.

segment.source: Run the SampleExperiment app you created in the previous section.
segment.target: Run the SampleExperiment app you created in the previous section.

segment.source: Confirm that you see a blue button.
segment.target: Confirm that you see a blue button.

segment.source: Note that it may take up to two minutes for your app to receive an updated variation assignment.
segment.target: Note that it may take up to two minutes for your app to receive an updated variation assignment.

segment.source: Related topics
segment.target: Related topics

segment.source: Define your experiment in the Dev Center dashboard
segment.target: Define your experiment in the Dev Center dashboard

segment.source: Code your app for experimentation
segment.target: Code your app for experimentation

segment.source: Manage your experiment in the Dev Center dashboard
segment.target: Manage your experiment in the Dev Center dashboard

segment.source: Run app experiments with A/B testing
segment.target: Run app experiments with A/B testing
